comment: I want to play the Blackmar-Diemer Gambit so let's see if David will oblige.

If black declines the pawn
offer, we get into French lines i.e.3...e6 4.e5 Nfd7 5.f4

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Nc3 d5 3. e4 dxe4 4. f3 exf3 5. Nxf3 e6
comment:
The Euwe Defence, here white can play the line 6.Bg5 Be7 7. Bd3
Nbd7, but I like 6.Bc4 with idea's on e6, & f7.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Nc3 d5 3. e4 dxe4 4. f3 exf3 5. Nxf3 e6 6. Bc4 Be7 7. O-O O-O
comment:
Now that David has castled, white can concentrate on attacking the King-side
position.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Nc3 d5 3. e4 dxe4 4. f3 exf3 5. Nxf3 e6 6. Bc4 Be7 7. O-O O-O 8. Qe1
comment:
With this idea in mind I would like to play the bishop back
to d3, and then play Qh4, h6 by black results in Bxh6 & after gxh6 Qxh6 black
is struggling.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Nc3 d5 3. e4 dxe4 4. f3 exf3 5. Nxf3 e6 6. Bc4 Be7 7. O-O O-O 8. Qe1 c5 9. Be3 a6 10. dxc5 Qa5
comment:
A lovely idea this, black
gives back the gambit pawn, with the idea of ..Bxc5 Bxc5 Qxc5+ picking up the
Bishop on c4!!

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Nc3 d5 3. e4 dxe4 4. f3 exf3 5. Nxf3 e6 6. Bc4 Be7 7. O-O O-O 8. Qe1 c5 9. Be3 a6 10. dxc5 Qa5 11. Nd5
comment:
Oops, someone left the coral gate open, and the
stallion goes berserk. If black plays Qxe1 white gains a bishop by virtue of
the check on e7!

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Nc3 d5 3. e4 dxe4 4. f3 exf3 5. Nxf3 e6 6. Bc4 Be7 7. O-O O-O 8. Qe1 c5 9. Be3 a6 10. dxc5 Qa5 11. Nd5 Qd8
1. d4 Nf6 2. Nc3 d5 3. e4 dxe4 4. f3 exf3 5. Nxf3 e6 6. Bc4 Be7 7. O-O O-O 8. Qe1 c5 9. Be3 a6 10. dxc5 Qa5 11. Nd5 Qd8 12. Nb6
comment:
David threw in the towel to avoid further mutilation, as
12...Ra7 13.c6 Nxc6 14.c3 Ng4 15.Nxc8 Qxc8 16.Bxa7 Nxa7 17.Bb3!
